content: Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification requirements. Exemption from notification requirements for state and local political committees under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include political committees of state or local candidates and state or local committees of political parties. The amendments take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 2. Exemption for certain state and local political committees from reporting requirements. The amendment exempts qualified State or local political organizations from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'qualified State or local political organization' refers to a political organization focused on influencing the selection of individuals for State or local public offices, subject to state reporting requirements. The curr_chunk provides information on expenditures, contributions, and individuals involved in a political organization. The curr_chunk discusses reporting requirements for organizations, including the public availability of reports and disregarding certain state law differences. The curr_chunk highlights that state laws must not require reporting amounts more than $300 greater than federal requirements and must not mandate the identification of certain details by organizations. The employer of a person who contributes to the organization. The organization must disclose the occupation of contributors, recipients of expenditures, purpose of expenditures, contribution dates, and expenditure dates. An organization will not lose its status as a qualified State or local political organization for minor errors in meeting reporting and inspection requirements, as long as the errors are promptly corrected. The organization described in the curr_chunk will not be considered as such if a candidate for or holder of Federal elective public office controls or participates in its direction, solicits contributions, or if solicitations result in minimal contributions without the organization's knowledge or consent. The amendments made by this section will take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization Taxable Income. Amendment made to section 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding persons required to make income tax returns. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Amendments made to sections 6104(b) and 6104(d) of the Code regarding disclosure and public inspection of annual returns. Code relating to public inspection of certain annual returns is amended in paragraph (1)(A)(i) and subparagraph (2) by removing references to returns by political organizations. Section 6033 of the Code is also amended to apply to political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more for the taxable year. Political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more must file an annual return with required information, similar to tax-exempt organizations under section 501(a), with modifications as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. For qualified State or local political organizations under section 527(e)(5), the threshold is $100,000. The Secretary may make modifications to require necessary information for section 527 purposes and additional information as deemed necessary. Mandatory exceptions from filing apply to certain organizations such as State or local political party committees, caucuses, and authorized committees. The curr_chunk outlines the types of committees that are required to report under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including authorized committees of candidates, national committees of political parties, House or Senate campaign committees, and political committees. The amendments made by this section, defined in section 301(4) of the Act, allow the Secretary to exempt organizations from filing information returns if deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. These amendments are retroactively effective as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION OF INTERACTION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, shall publicize the effect of the amendments made by this Act and the interaction of requirements to file notifications or reports under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided shall be included in any appropriate form, instruction, notice, or guidance issued to the public regarding reporting requirements of political organizations. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, will publicize the impact of the amendments made by this Act on reporting requirements for political organizations under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive taxes or amounts imposed on organizations for failure to comply with requirements if due to reasonable cause, effective after June 30, 2000. SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS TO SECTION 527 ORGANIZATION DISCLOSURE PROVISIONS. SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS TO SECTION 527 ORGANIZATION DISCLOSURE PROVISIONS. Paragraph (4) of section 527(i) is amended to include exempt function income. Paragraph (1) of section 527(j) is amended to address assessment and collection procedures for amounts. The text discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to penalties, electronic filings, and fraudulent returns. It includes changes to the assessment and collection procedures for amounts imposed under subtitle F. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to reporting requirements for section 527 organizations, such as adding details like date and purpose to reports and allowing for electronic filing. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code now require electronic filing for organizations expecting contributions or expenditures over $50,000 in a calendar year. Public access to notices and reports is also mandated. The Secretary must make notices and reports available for public inspection online within 48 hours of filing. The database of these documents must be searchable by names, states, zip codes, and custodians of records. The database of notices and reports must include names, states, zip codes, custodians of records, directors, organizations related entities, contributors, employers of contributors, recipients of expenditures, ranges of contributions and expenditures, and time periods. It should be downloadable. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subparagraph regarding organizations claiming exemptions. Additionally, there is a provision for notifying about material changes in information required under paragraph (3) of the code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new provision for notifying about material changes in information required under paragraph (3) not later than 30 days after such change. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision for notifying material changes within 30 days. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to failures after the enactment date, while subsection (c) takes effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. The amendments made by subsections (d), (e)(1), (f), (e)(2), (e)(3), and (g) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 have specific effective dates for reports and notices to be filed after certain enactment dates. The amendments made by subsection (g) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply to material changes filed on or after June 30, 2003. A transition rule allows for a 30-day period after enactment for filing notices for material changes. After the enactment of this Act, a 45-day period is allowed for certain actions to be taken. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF AMENDMENTS ON EXISTING DISCLOSURES. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
